Award.AbstractNarration:
Antonio Montalban will study problems in Computability Theory. He is interested in the interplay between complexity and mathematics. In mathematics, as we all know, some structures are more complicated than others, some constructions more complicated than others, and some proofs more complicated than others. He plans to apply methods from computability theory to study the complexity of various areas of both classical mathematics and foundations of mathematics.

One of our objectives is to study of the computational properties of counterexamples to Vaught's conjecture, which is one of the most well-known and longest-standing conjectures in logic. This is with an eye towards either showing that those counterexamples do not exist, or just trying to understand them if they do exist. Montalban has already shown that being a counterexample to Vaught's conjecture is equivalent to a couple of purely computability-theoretic properties, and he has in mind a few other properties that might also end up being equivalent.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I work in Mathematical Logic and focus on Computability Theory.  In general terms,my research studies the interplay between complexity and mathematics.  As logicians, we have developed techniques to analyze and understand the complexity of many sorts of objects, including binary sequences, structures, constructions, proofs, and so forth. Computability Theory is the ara of logic that deals with the complexity of infinite countable objects. I have worked in various areas within computability theory.  But a central theme in my work, and one of the focus of this proposal, was the study of on-a-cone properties, which turned out to be an important tool to connect structural and computational properties. This idea had been around before, but its  applicability of this idea to the study the behavior of natural objects, and the extent to which structure emerges when considering properties on a cone has only started tobecome apparent with my work of the last few years.

 

I have also worked in Computable Structure Theroy. In this area, we study the interplay between complexity and structure.  By complexity, werefer to descriptional or computational complexity, in the sense of how difficult it is to describeor compute certain objects.  By structure, we refer to algebraic or structural properties ofmathematical structures --- mathematical structures like graphs, rings, fields, or linear orderings,which consist of a domain on which there are relations, functions, and constants.  The setting isthat of infinite countable structures, thus the appropriate tools come from computability theory. Mainly, in the past few years, I have worked on developing new theory and new frameworks for further understanding old ideas. I am in the midle of writting a book, titled "Computable Structure Theory" that will include all of this material. I have already signed a contract with Cambridge University Press for its publication.
